Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic on Shimura Varieties and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project lies in a subfield of mathematics known as arithmetic geometry. Many of the questions in the project are motivated by the philosophy that information about algebraic equations over the integers can be obtained by geometric methods. Solution to the problems under study in this project will have substantial impact on research in cryptography, theoretical physics, and quantum computing.

In more detail, the investigator will study the connections between arithmetic on a Shimura variety and L-functions and Eisenstein series. In different projects, he aims to prove various arithmetic Siegel-Weil formulas, determine when a special divisor is cohomologically trivial but not rational trivial in a Picard modular surface, prove a conjecture of Gross and Zagier on algebraicity of CM values, continue to work on Colmez conjecture, and study the rationality and integrality of unitary modular forms in terms of their Fourier-Jacobi coefficients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During last few years, I have been trying to further understand arithmetic on Shimura varieties (Kudla program) and use these knowledge to prove interesting classical conjectures in number theory. During this period, I have published 11 research  papers in top math journals, including Invent. Math.,  J. European Mathematical Journal, Astérisque, International  Mathematical Research Notices, Transaction of American Mathematical Society, Advances in Mathematics,  and Algebra and Number Theory. Two other papers have been submitted for publication.  Concretely,  


(a). In my joint work with J. Bruinier, B. Howard, S. Kudla, and M. Rapoport,  we proved the modularity of the generating series of arithmetic divisors (cycles of codimension 1) in a unitary Shimura variety of signature $(n-1, 1)$ and its applications. In an ongoing joint project with J. Bruinier,  J. Funke, S. Kudla, and S. Sankaran, we intend to prove a fundamental modularity result of the generating series of arithmetic cycles  of codimension bigger than $1$ in a unitary Shimura variety.  This line of research is fundamental in the study of Shimura varieties.
(b). In a joint work with J. Bruinier  and a separate joint work with Tuoping Du, we have proved important cases of arithmetic Siegel-Weil formula---part of Kudla program.

(c).   In a joint work  with  J. Bruinier and S. Ehlen, we proved an average version of algebraicity conjecture of Gross-Zagier on the CM value of the higher weight Green function of over 30 years.  We also extend the conjecture to a much more general situation. 
(d). In a joint work with Hongbo Yin and another joint work with Hongbo Yin and Peng Yu, we applied general results on Shimura varieties to modular curves, and discovered a couple factorizations of difference of CM values of some well-known modular functions, including Lambda functions. In  another joint work with Yingkun Li, we further proved a conjecture of Yui-Zagier conjecture on the norm of difference of CM values of the Weber functions.
(e).   In an ongoing joint project with Qiao He and Yousheng Shi, we are trying to prove some local arithmetic Siegel-Weil formula for $U(n-1, 1)$-Shimura varieties  at ramified primes---Kudla-Rapoport conjecture. We have already proved the case $n=2$, which was submitted for publication. We are close to prove the case $n=3$ and have made significant progress in general cases.
(f). In my joint work with Hongbo Yin, we discovered a new method to prove new cases of the  Colmez conjecture. My student S. Parenti extended this to more cases.
